title: Editor's Picks #569
author: Nam Henderson
excerpt: Bryan C. Lee, Jr., NOMA, FAIA President of the National Organization of Minority Architects penned an editorial in which he elaborated
text: Bryan C. Lee, Jr., NOMA, FAIA President of the National Organization of Minority Architects penned an editorial in which he elaborated "on the significance of anti-DEI positions in our profession" and explained how "The consequences of our profession acquiescing to this moment could be catastrophic if not handled with the appropriate level of wisdom, honesty, and disdain."  Ryan Singer applauded "it is crucial that our unwavering commitment to fairness remains steadfast…True meritocracy requires dismantling barriers, not ignoring them." News The New Yorker published a lengthy look into Lord Foster’s world. Most were not impressed with reallynotmyname noting "It's good reading in the sense that it is not totally flattering and goes into detail about his finances and business operations.  99% of articles in the media about starchitects are pure puff/hagiography." Heatherwick Studio released conceptual designs for an adaptive reuse of the aging Riverfront Plaza/Belvedere area in downtown Louisville, Kentucky. sameolddoctor opined "This is even worse than the shit Koolhaas had proposed...back in the day" with davidwimmer adding "Seriously though, the idea of hiding some of the highway and developing a green space riverfront observation park over top of a convention space is wonderful.  Just loose [sic] the ridiculous hyperbolic roof forms that make most of the park unusable and block the views." Image courtesy City of LouisvilleImage courtesy City of LouisvilleGensler is pursuing an office-to-residential conversion of the former Pfizer Corporation headquarters at 229 East 42nd Street in Manhattan. Although many thought the floor plans and layouts were less than ideal despite the talk of co-living and shared amenities Janosh argued "Single Residential Occupancy buildings have existing [sic] for more than 150 years in New York and it's a very good way to add housing by converting forty year old Class C office buildings. Many of these have floor plates too deep for conventional units and placing the common restrooms next to the core is a great solution." Bjarke Ingels Group (BIG) is working on designs for the Opera & Ballet Theatre of Kosovo. Orhan Ayyüce saw in the design a reference to Sufi whirling, while Will Galloway felt "The recent fabric themed buildings from BIG are all quite good. Much as I love the pixel-buildings the more bendy buildings read automatically as more poetic and spatially ambitious." Image courtesy BloomNews about a Chicago nonprofit’s shelter references "trauma-informed design" which led to a discussion about interior design buzzwords and the importance of pre and post-occupancy data collection. seanmcguire who worked on the project jumped into the fray "we are working on a proposal for (Gensler funded) research grants to perform a post occupancy analysis…Trauma informed designed is a relatively novel concept, and there needs to be more empirical analysis into its efficacy in these settings." Non Sequitur seemed to speak for many "This is straight up pornographic.  I'll need a few minutes alone with these pictures" in response to Red Sol, a seaside resort, in Dhërmi, Albania by Bofill Taller de Arquitectura. The Snøhetta-designed El Paso Children’s Museum completed construction in Texas. The_Crow thought it was "A weirdly post modern and flat facade from Snohetta" though others were more complimentary "it’s fun" and "love it". Image credit - Casey DunnBlogs/Firms/Work Updates Cool Gardens 2025, presented by Storefront Manitoba, invites proposals by individual artists/designers or teams for temporary garden installations. March 9th is the deadline to apply. ICYMI last fall, the firms CBA architectes and Espace Libre – landscaper transformed Rouen’s former École Normale d’Institutrices (ENI). interior © Julien FalsimagneOver at her blog Cristina Cotruta was inspired "to experiment with AI as an architect" after encountering "particularly vehement and rude" comments about AI-generated designs from others in the profession. She’s found that "One of the most compelling outcomes of this process was the extraction of cross-sectional linework through a straightforward clipping section in Rhino." Looking for work? Dattner Architects is seeking a "talented designer" with "2-4 years’ professional experience" to join their NYC office. OpenScope Studio which operates through California, wants someone with "3-6 years experience" and notes "The job will require attendance at both our office in San Francisco and at the San Francisco International Airport."Boston based Payette is hiring for a Project Manager with "At least eight years".Schools The University of Sharjah shared work from Architectural Design II led by Instructor: Dr. Aref Maksoud. The University of New Mexico reminded that submissions for 2025 Jeff Harnar Awards are open until March 24, 2025 for "built and unbuilt work in the Architecture and Landscape Architecture categories in the Four Corner States (AZ, CO, NM, UT)". A team from the University of Stuttgart in Germany published research into "mycelium growth, and material properties in 3D-printed mycelium-based composites (MBCs)." Image credit - Gomaa, Karazi, Chau, ITECH University of Stuttgart, 2023Looking for a new gig in academia? Weitzman School of Design is accepting applications for either a full-time, tenure-track position to start in 2026 or a Professor/Associate Professor of Practice in Architecture to start as early as fall 2025. Not interested in higher education? Mountain Views School District seeking an Innovation Lab Teacher who is "passionate about design, technology and education to join Woodstock Union High School and Middle School (WUHSMS), in Woodstock, VT". Discussion/Threads Back in January Kwoz44 was "at a wit's end when it comes to comchecks." b3tadine[sutures] jumped right in with a lengthy response which ended with "Finally, if this local hoodlum won’t listen, call your state building department, and have them lay the smackdown." OddArchitect advised "In this situation you're going to need to use the IEBC to show compliance" then in response to some wondering if this was just user error clarified "Sometimes when a new version of the IECC comes out Comcheck takes a while to properly incorporate it. When the OP first posted the 2024 IECC for existing buildings didn’t work. It appears to now." BluecornGroup is looking for tips on "technical manuals that might be used by a manufacturer…for thermally-broken aluminum storefront extrusions" and OddArchitect had a "really nerdy" question about coatings for Touching up cut galvanized steel. For the former Non Sequitur recommended simplifying things and just working with Reynaers "instead of frankensteining pieces together?" Though bowling_ball cautioned that based on a recent project they have some room to grow when it comes to detailing and shop drawings for cold climates. natematt also suggested checking out "YKKAP, Kawneer, Oldcastle, Arcadia, EFCO, or other Aluminum systems." For the later, Kowski referenced "AGA recommendations as well as ASTM A780". Though Everyday Architect goes even further "Repair of the galvanizing in accordance with ASTM A780 is what we typically require, but we've never had good experience with repair by zinc-rich paint allowed by the standard. So we go the extra step of excluding that as an option and requiring either zinc solder or metallizing spray when we really need to be sure we'll get good repair...Over the galvanized steel we usually have a high-performance coating system specified as well." Finally Donna Sink posted "images and…sketches from the Exhibit Columbus 2025 presentations" she thinks "these are some of the best ideas we've yet seen…this year's installations are going to be excellent!" Wood Guy liked Miller Prize winner AD-WO’s canopy "it defines the space and resembles sidewalk grates, emphasizing the underground aspect and traveling back in time…Cool project" and Josh Mings chimed in "These are pretty good...the curatorial team definitely did well with the participants!" UDRF from New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT)- Aaron Goldstein and Andrew Fu with The Steel Horsie via Donna SinkAdditionally Over at MOLD, Anand Pandian wrote about the 2023 Venice Architecture Biennale, Materials of Decay, Practices of Repair and more.
html:
Bryan C. Lee, Jr., NOMA, FAIA President of the National Organization of Minority Architects penned an editorial in which he elaborated "on the significance of anti-DEI positions in our profession" and explained how "The consequences of our profession acquiescing to this moment could be catastrophic if not handled with the appropriate level of wisdom, honesty, and disdain." 

Ryan Singer applauded "it is crucial that our unwavering commitment to fairness remains steadfast…True meritocracy requires dismantling barriers, not ignoring them."

News

The New Yorker published a lengthy look into Lord Foster’s world. Most were not impressed with reallynotmyname noting "It's good reading in the sense that it is not totally flattering and goes into detail about his finances and business operations.  99% of articles in the media about starchitects are pure puff/hagiography."

Heatherwick Studio released conceptual designs for an adaptive reuse of the aging Riverfront Plaza/Belvedere area in downtown Louisville, Kentucky. sameolddoctor opined "This is even worse than the shit Koolhaas had proposed...back in the day" with davidwimmer adding "Seriously though, the idea of hiding some of the highway and developing a green space riverfront observation park over top of a convention space is wonderful.  Just loose [sic] the ridiculous hyperbolic roof forms that make most of the park unusable and block the views."

Gensler is pursuing an office-to-residential conversion of the former Pfizer Corporation headquarters at 229 East 42nd Street in Manhattan. Although many thought the floor plans and layouts were less than ideal despite the talk of co-living and shared amenities Janosh argued "Single Residential Occupancy buildings have existing [sic] for more than 150 years in New York and it's a very good way to add housing by converting forty year old Class C office buildings. Many of these have floor plates too deep for conventional units and placing the common restrooms next to the core is a great solution."

Bjarke Ingels Group (BIG) is working on designs for the Opera & Ballet Theatre of Kosovo. Orhan Ayyüce saw in the design a reference to Sufi whirling, while Will Galloway felt "The recent fabric themed buildings from BIG are all quite good. Much as I love the pixel-buildings the more bendy buildings read automatically as more poetic and spatially ambitious."

News about a Chicago nonprofit’s shelter references "trauma-informed design" which led to a discussion about interior design buzzwords and the importance of pre and post-occupancy data collection. seanmcguire who worked on the project jumped into the fray "we are working on a proposal for (Gensler funded) research grants to perform a post occupancy analysis…Trauma informed designed is a relatively novel concept, and there needs to be more empirical analysis into its efficacy in these settings."

Non Sequitur seemed to speak for many "This is straight up pornographic.  I'll need a few minutes alone with these pictures" in response to Red Sol, a seaside resort, in Dhërmi, Albania by Bofill Taller de Arquitectura.

The Snøhetta-designed El Paso Children’s Museum completed construction in Texas. The_Crow thought it was "A weirdly post modern and flat facade from Snohetta" though others were more complimentary "it’s fun" and "love it".

Blogs/Firms/Work Updates

Cool Gardens 2025, presented by Storefront Manitoba, invites proposals by individual artists/designers or teams for temporary garden installations. March 9th is the deadline to apply.

ICYMI last fall, the firms CBA architectes and Espace Libre – landscaper transformed Rouen’s former École Normale d’Institutrices (ENI).

Over at her blog Cristina Cotruta was inspired "to experiment with AI as an architect" after encountering "particularly vehement and rude" comments about AI-generated designs from others in the profession. She’s found that "One of the most compelling outcomes of this process was the extraction of cross-sectional linework through a straightforward clipping section in Rhino."

Looking for work?

  • Dattner Architects is seeking a "talented designer" with "2-4 years’ professional experience" to join their NYC office.
  • OpenScope Studio which operates through California, wants someone with "3-6 years experience" and notes "The job will require attendance at both our office in San Francisco and at the San Francisco International Airport."
  • Boston based Payette is hiring for a Project Manager with "At least eight years".

Schools

The University of Sharjah shared work from Architectural Design II led by Instructor: Dr. Aref Maksoud.


The University of New Mexico reminded that submissions for 2025 Jeff Harnar Awards are open until March 24, 2025 for "built and unbuilt work in the Architecture and Landscape Architecture categories in the Four Corner States (AZ, CO, NM, UT)".

A team from the University of Stuttgart in Germany published research into "mycelium growth, and material properties in 3D-printed mycelium-based composites (MBCs)."

Looking for a new gig in academia? Weitzman School of Design is accepting applications for either a full-time, tenure-track position to start in 2026 or a Professor/Associate Professor of Practice in Architecture to start as early as fall 2025.

Not interested in higher education? Mountain Views School District seeking an Innovation Lab Teacher who is "passionate about design, technology and education to join Woodstock Union High School and Middle School (WUHSMS), in Woodstock, VT".


Discussion/Threads

Back in January Kwoz44 was "at a wit's end when it comes to comchecks." b3tadine[sutures] jumped right in with a lengthy response which ended with "Finally, if this local hoodlum won’t listen, call your state building department, and have them lay the smackdown." OddArchitect advised "In this situation you're going to need to use the IEBC to show compliance" then in response to some wondering if this was just user error clarified "Sometimes when a new version of the IECC comes out Comcheck takes a while to properly incorporate it. When the OP first posted the 2024 IECC for existing buildings didn’t work. It appears to now."

BluecornGroup is looking for tips on "technical manuals that might be used by a manufacturer…for thermally-broken aluminum storefront extrusions" and OddArchitect had a "really nerdy" question about coatings for Touching up cut galvanized steel.

For the former Non Sequitur recommended simplifying things and just working with Reynaers "instead of frankensteining pieces together?" Though bowling_ball cautioned that based on a recent project they have some room to grow when it comes to detailing and shop drawings for cold climates. natematt also suggested checking out "YKKAP, Kawneer, Oldcastle, Arcadia, EFCO, or other Aluminum systems."

For the later, Kowski referenced "AGA recommendations as well as ASTM A780". Though Everyday Architect goes even further "Repair of the galvanizing in accordance with ASTM A780 is what we typically require, but we've never had good experience with repair by zinc-rich paint allowed by the standard. So we go the extra step of excluding that as an option and requiring either zinc solder or metallizing spray when we really need to be sure we'll get good repair...Over the galvanized steel we usually have a high-performance coating system specified as well."

Finally Donna Sink posted "images and…sketches from the Exhibit Columbus 2025 presentations" she thinks "these are some of the best ideas we've yet seen…this year's installations are going to be excellent!" Wood Guy liked Miller Prize winner AD-WO’s canopy "it defines the space and resembles sidewalk grates, emphasizing the underground aspect and traveling back in time…Cool project" and Josh Mings chimed in "These are pretty good...the curatorial team definitely did well with the participants!"

Additionally

Over at MOLD, Anand Pandian wrote about the 2023 Venice Architecture Biennale, Materials of Decay, Practices of Repair and more.
